articles.headline: Russia Steps Up Help for Rebels in Ukraine War
articles.snippet: Russia has accelerated its intervention, moving more of its own troops to its border with Ukraine, American and Ukrainian officials said on Friday.
articles.abstract: Russia has accelerated its intervention, moving more of its own troops to its border with Ukraine, American and Ukrainian officials said on Friday.
articles.lead_paragraph: KIEV, Ukraine — Rather than backing down after last week’s downing of a civilian passenger jet, Russia appears to be intervening more aggressively in the war in eastern Ukraine in what American and Ukrainian officials call a dangerous escalation that will almost certainly force more robust retaliation from the United States and Europe.
articles.byline: By David M. Herszenhorn and Peter Baker

articles.headline: Text and Ride in India
articles.snippet: In a country with heavy traffic congestion and poor public transportation, companies are finding new ways to better connect drivers and passengers.
articles.abstract: In a country with heavy traffic congestion and poor public transportation, companies are finding new ways to better connect drivers and passengers.
articles.lead_paragraph: PUNE, India — When Praveen Narayan Dusane first started driving an auto-rickshaw in this crowded college town, he had to hustle for every rupee. He could wait hours at a rickshaw stand for passengers. He fought with other drivers and haggled with passengers over the fares. Typically, he earned just 300 rupees, or roughly $5, during a 12-hour shift.

articles.headline: Trail of Medical Missteps in a Peace Corps Death
articles.snippet: The death of Nick Castle, a 23-year-old volunteer in China, raises serious questions about Peace Corps medical care.
articles.abstract: The death of Nick Castle, a 23-year-old volunteer in China, raises serious questions about Peace Corps medical care.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRENTWOOD, Calif. — Nick Castle had just graduated from the University of California, Berkeley, when he loaded up his backpack with Mandarin-language books and set off for rural China to teach in the Peace Corps. Seven months later, in January 2013, a 2 a.m. telephone call jolted his parents awake.

articles.headline: Insurance Coverage for Fertility Treatments Varies Widely
articles.snippet: From 2006 to 2010, 7.4 million women used infertility services, like an evaluation by a specialist, drug therapy or in vitro fertilization.
articles.abstract: From 2006 to 2010, 7.4 million women used infertility services, like an evaluation by a specialist, drug therapy or in vitro fertilization.
articles.lead_paragraph: Sarah Patterson, a 27-year-old nurse, suffered four miscarriages over the last four years because of several medical problems, including a condition that causes cysts to form on the ovaries. After her second loss, she said, her husband asked for a divorce because he could not handle the stress.

articles.headline: Solar Industry Is Rebalanced by U.S. Pressure on China
articles.snippet: The Commerce Department on Friday found that Chinese companies had dumped their products on the American market at below cost, and imposed duties of 10.74 percent to 55.49 percent.
articles.abstract: The Commerce Department on Friday found that Chinese companies had dumped their products on the American market at below cost, and imposed duties of 10.74 percent to 55.49 percent.
articles.lead_paragraph: Even as regulators continue to wrestle with the protracted trade conflict with China over solar panels, the case has already started to reshape the industry, lifting manufacturers based outside China while also raising prices of panels for developers.
articles.byline: By Diane Cardwell and Keith Bradsher

articles.headline: Move to Center Divides G.O.P. in North Carolina
articles.snippet: The state's Republican governor and House speaker are both struggling to make peace with conservatives as they try to appeal to more moderate voters.
articles.abstract: The state's Republican governor and House speaker are both struggling to make peace with conservatives as they try to appeal to more moderate voters.
articles.lead_paragraph: RALEIGH, N.C. — The objective of the Republican Party here last year was clear: Unleash the pent-up conservative revolution in a state where the party had not controlled the state legislature and governor’s office for more than a century.

articles.headline: Israel’s Outspoken Envoy Is Wise to U.S. Ways
articles.snippet: Ambassador Ron Dermer, a former American citizen, has such a close relationship to Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel that he has been called “Bibi’s brain.”
articles.abstract: Ambassador Ron Dermer, a former American citizen, has such a close relationship to Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel that he has been called “Bibi’s brain.”
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As an undergraduate at the University of Pennsylvania, Ron Dermer reluctantly accepted an assignment to argue that Israel should be condemned for its treatment of Palestinians.

articles.headline: Ex-Chief of C.I.A. Shapes Response to Detention Report
articles.snippet: George J. Tenet, the former C.I.A. director, has been quietly engineering a counterattack against a Senate panel’s finding that officials misled Congress about an interrogation program.
articles.abstract: George J. Tenet, the former C.I.A. director, has been quietly engineering a counterattack against a Senate panel’s finding that officials misled Congress about an interrogation program.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Just after the Senate Intelligence Committee voted in April to declassify hundreds of pages of a withering report on the Central Intelligence Agency’s detention and interrogation program, C.I.A. Director John O. Brennan convened a meeting of the men who had played a role overseeing the program in its seven-year history.

articles.headline: Private Equity’s Free Pass
articles.snippet: On their way to big profits, private equity firms often act like investment banks, but aren’t subject to the same rules.
articles.abstract: On their way to big profits, private equity firms often act like investment banks, but aren’t subject to the same rules.
articles.lead_paragraph: For thousands of hobbyists, the local Michaels Stores outlet is a must-stop shop for scrapbooks, dried flowers, crochet hooks, sewing notions and dozens of other do-it-yourself paraphernalia.

articles.headline: For Coconut Waters, a Street Fight for Shelf Space
articles.snippet: Why is coconut water everywhere? Because two companies battled for market share, one yoga studio and corner store at a time.
articles.abstract: Why is coconut water everywhere? Because two companies battled for market share, one yoga studio and corner store at a time.
articles.lead_paragraph: Like kale salads and Robin Thicke, coconut water seems to have jumped from invisible to unavoidable without a pause in the realm of the vaguely familiar.

articles.headline: Pentagon Plan Would Help Ukraine Target Rebel Missiles
articles.snippet: A proposal would let the Obama administration give precise locations of surface-to-air missiles controlled by Russian-backed separatists in eastern Ukraine so the Ukrainian government could target them.
articles.abstract: A proposal would let the Obama administration give precise locations of surface-to-air missiles controlled by Russian-backed separatists in eastern Ukraine so the Ukrainian government could target them.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Pentagon and American intelligence agencies are developing plans that would enable the Obama administration to provide specific locations of surface-to-air missiles controlled by Russian-backed separatists in eastern Ukraine so the Ukrainian government could target them for destruction, American officials said.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: Grandson Proudly Squirms in Carter’s Footsteps
articles.snippet: As Georgia's Democratic nominee for governor, Jason Carter has distanced himself from many beliefs of his grandfather, former President Jimmy Carter.
articles.abstract: As Georgia's Democratic nominee for governor, Jason Carter has distanced himself from many beliefs of his grandfather, former President Jimmy Carter.
articles.lead_paragraph: PLAINS, Ga. — Like many candidates, Jason Carter, the Democratic nominee for governor in Georgia, is courting the Jewish vote. But when Mr. Carter, a state senator, declared his “powerful connection” to Israel, it was more than a campaign sound bite.

articles.headline: Race in Toyland: A Nonwhite Doll Crosses Over
articles.snippet: The blockbuster success of merchandise based on the “Doc McStuffins” cartoon reflects changing demographics, but what also differentiates Doc is her crossover appeal.
articles.abstract: The blockbuster success of merchandise based on the “Doc McStuffins” cartoon reflects changing demographics, but what also differentiates Doc is her crossover appeal.
articles.lead_paragraph: Jade Goss, age 2, looks as if she just stepped out of the wildly popular “Doc McStuffins” cartoon.
articles.byline: By Elizabeth A. Harris and Tanzina Vega

articles.headline: Taliban Making Military Gains in Afghanistan
articles.snippet: The insurgents’ increasing domination of key strategic areas has cast doubts on the government’s stability after the United States completes its withdrawal of combat troops.
articles.abstract: The insurgents’ increasing domination of key strategic areas has cast doubts on the government’s stability after the United States completes its withdrawal of combat troops.
articles.lead_paragraph: MAHMUD RAQI, Afghanistan — Taliban fighters are scoring early gains in several strategic areas near the capital this summer, inflicting heavy casualties and casting new doubt on the ability of Afghan forces to contain the insurgency as the United States moves to complete its withdrawal of combat troops, according to Afghan officials and local elders.

articles.headline: In Ferry Deaths, a South Korean Tycoon’s Downfall
articles.snippet: The sinking of the ferry Sewol killed 304 passengers and exposed a web of questionable business practices by Yoo Byung-eun, who was found dead in June.
articles.abstract: The sinking of the ferry Sewol killed 304 passengers and exposed a web of questionable business practices by Yoo Byung-eun, who was found dead in June.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — After all the lavish galas in his honor at landmarks like the Louvre and Versailles, the tens of thousands of devotees following his religious teachings for decades, the hundreds of homes and businesses reportedly stashed around the globe, Yoo Byung-eun ended up alone, his body splayed on its back and rotting in the weeds, empty liquor bottles by his side.
articles.byline: By Choe Sang-Hun, Martin Fackler, Alison Leigh Cowan and Scott Sayare

articles.headline: At Front Lines, Bearing Witness in Real Time
articles.snippet: We used to witness war in the rearview mirror. But journalists often now deliver what they see via Twitter, before consulting with headquarters, and it has made for more visceral reporting.
articles.abstract: We used to witness war in the rearview mirror. But journalists often now deliver what they see via Twitter, before consulting with headquarters, and it has made for more visceral reporting.
articles.lead_paragraph: My social media feed has taken a bloody turn in the last few weeks, and I’m hardly alone. Along with the usual Twitter wisecracking and comments on incremental news, I have seen bodies scattered across fields and hospitals in Ukraine and Gaza. I have read posts from reporters who felt threatened, horrified and revolted.

articles.headline: Can Reddit Grow Up?
articles.snippet: Efforts by the freewheeling online community to monetize without driving away its 114 million monthly users will require appealing to advertisers without sacrificing values like personal data privacy.
articles.abstract: Efforts by the freewheeling online community to monetize without driving away its 114 million monthly users will require appealing to advertisers without sacrificing values like personal data privacy.
articles.lead_paragraph: Since its founding nine years ago, Reddit has stuck to its own weird guns.

articles.headline: Outside Money Drives a Deluge of Political Ads
articles.snippet: Since the Supreme Court's 2010 Citizens United ruling, lavish spending by outside groups has created a nearly nonstop campaign season with a harsh, negative tone.
articles.abstract: Since the Supreme Court's 2010 Citizens United ruling, lavish spending by outside groups has created a nearly nonstop campaign season with a harsh, negative tone.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — An explosion of spending on political advertising on television — set to break $2 billion in congressional races, with overall spots up nearly 70 percent since the 2010 midterm election — is accelerating the rise of moneyed interests and wresting control from the candidates’ own efforts to reach voters.

articles.headline: Rallying for The Salt Lake Tribune as a City Changes
articles.snippet: Activists are seeking to block changes to an operating agreement between The Salt Lake Tribune and the Mormon Church-owned Deseret News.
articles.abstract: Activists are seeking to block changes to an operating agreement between The Salt Lake Tribune and the Mormon Church-owned Deseret News.
articles.lead_paragraph: SALT LAKE CITY — At 8:30 on a recent Thursday morning, Terry Orme, publisher and editor of The Salt Lake Tribune, walked toward his corner office wheeling a cooler full of beer behind him.

articles.headline: Fast-Food Workers Intensify Fight for $15 an Hour
articles.snippet: About 1,200 workers from around the country gathered in Illinois at an event largely underwritten by the Service Employees International Union, but the U.S. Chamber of Commerce is dubious of the union’s intentions.
articles.abstract: About 1,200 workers from around the country gathered in Illinois at an event largely underwritten by the Service Employees International Union, but the U.S. Chamber of Commerce is dubious of the union’s intentions.
articles.lead_paragraph: ADDISON, Ill. — As labor gatherings go, this one was highly unusual — 68 workers arrived on charter buses from St. Louis, 100 from New York City and 180 from Alabama, Georgia and the Carolinas. Fifty flew in from Los Angeles and two dozen from Seattle.

articles.headline: Even Gaza Truce Is Hard to Win, Kerry Is Finding
articles.snippet: Israel and Hamas both see reasons to continue fighting, and Israeli officials appear dismissive of John Kerry’s aims in a way that few American secretaries of state have faced.
articles.abstract: Israel and Hamas both see reasons to continue fighting, and Israeli officials appear dismissive of John Kerry’s aims in a way that few American secretaries of state have faced.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — After failing to win a deal to end fighting in Gaza last week, Secretary of State John Kerry is trying to salvage Plan B: a succession of temporary cease-fires that he hopes might yet open the door to Israeli and Palestinian negotiations for a long-term solution.

articles.headline: Large Crowds Spend Little at Comic-Con
articles.snippet: Though Comic-Con International is far and away San Diego’s largest annual convention, the mobs of pop culture enthusiasts who attend it are not big spenders.
articles.abstract: Though Comic-Con International is far and away San Diego’s largest annual convention, the mobs of pop culture enthusiasts who attend it are not big spenders.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN DIEGO — “The great thing about the comics industry is that it’s driven by passion — it isn’t really driven by money,” said Royden Lepp, a graphic novelist, who was speaking on one of the scores of panels at the Comic-Con International convention on Friday.
articles.byline: By Michael Cieply and Brooks Barnes

articles.headline: Fear of Ebola Breeds a Terror of Physicians
articles.snippet: Health workers with Doctors Without Borders have been threatened with knives, stones and machetes by Guineans who blame them for spreading the deadly virus.
articles.abstract: Health workers with Doctors Without Borders have been threatened with knives, stones and machetes by Guineans who blame them for spreading the deadly virus.
articles.lead_paragraph: KOLO BENGOU, Guinea — Eight youths, some armed with slingshots and machetes, stood warily alongside a rutted dirt road at an opening in the high reeds, the path to the village of Kolo Bengou. The deadly Ebola virus is believed to have infected several people in the village, and the youths were blocking the path to prevent health workers from entering.

articles.headline: A Surrogacy Agency That Delivered Heartache
articles.snippet: As unregulated surrogacy agencies proliferate, the story of Planet Hospital stands as a cautionary tale about their ability to prey on vulnerable clients who do not notice the red flags.
articles.abstract: As unregulated surrogacy agencies proliferate, the story of Planet Hospital stands as a cautionary tale about their ability to prey on vulnerable clients who do not notice the red flags.
articles.lead_paragraph: CANCÚN, Mexico — Rudy Rupak, the founder of Planet Hospital, a medical tourism company based in California, was never shy about self-promotion. Over the last decade he has held forth about how his company has helped Americans head overseas for affordable tummy tucks and hip replacements. And after he expanded his business to include surrogacy in India for Western couples grappling with infertility — and then in Thailand, and last year, Mexico — he increasingly took credit for the global spread of surrogacy.

articles.headline: $50 Billion Awarded in Breakup of Yukos
articles.snippet: A three-member tribunal called the seizure of the Russian oil company a politically driven campaign to neutralize its owner and put its assets under state control.
articles.abstract: A three-member tribunal called the seizure of the Russian oil company a politically driven campaign to neutralize its owner and put its assets under state control.
articles.lead_paragraph: An international court has awarded the shareholders of the now-defunct Yukos oil company more than $50 billion, ruling that the Russian government wrongly seized the company from one of the country’s most powerful oligarchs.

articles.headline: With Microsoft in Sights, China Starts to Squeeze U.S. Tech Companies
articles.snippet: An agency that enforces antimonopoly laws visited company offices in four cities, as the country more closely scrutinizes multinational companies.
articles.abstract: An agency that enforces antimonopoly laws visited company offices in four cities, as the country more closely scrutinizes multinational companies.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIJING — China, once the hottest growth market for United States technology companies, is turning chillier.
articles.byline: By Andrew Jacobs, Chris Buckley and Nick Wingfield
